translated_dialog: My servingman-monster is so drowned in the wine hes drunk that he cant even talk. For my part, not even the sea can drown me. Before I reached the shore from the shipwreck, I swam a hundred and five miles. Therefore, monster, youll be my lieutenant, or my flag-bearer.
og_response: Your lieutenant, if you list. Hes no standard.

translated_dialog: Won't you be glad to see that pretentious, rascally dog get humiliated?
og_response: I would exult, man. You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

translated_dialog: What's going on now?
og_response: The Turkish preparation makes for Rhodes, So was I bid report here to the stateBy Signior Angelo.

translated_dialog: If there were no other reason
og_response: 'Tis but so, I warrant.

translated_dialog: "Don't be afraid of my greatness." It was well written.
og_response: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

translated_dialog: If I can trust my eyes, this is a beautiful sight.
og_response: O Setebos, these be brave spirits indeed!    How fine my master is!   I am afraid    He will chastise me.

translated_dialog: What, you mean my face?
og_response: Well aimed of such a young one.

translated_dialog: Boy, lead these gentlemen to my daughters, and tell them that these are their tutors, so make sure to treat them well.
og_response: We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner. You are passing welcome,And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

translated_dialog: Please, read it like a sane person.
og_response: So I do, madonna. But to read his right wits is to readthus.Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

translated_dialog: He is a knight. His sword has never been used in battle, and he was knighted through his court connections rather than his battle skill, but he's a devil when he's fighting a private duel. He's killed three people, and his anger is so great right now that the only thing he'll be satisfied with is seeing you dead and buried. "Kill or be killed, it doesn't matter" is his motto.
og_response: I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady.   I am no fighter.   I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor. Belike this is a man of that quirk.

translated_dialog: What? Youre feeling moody? What is it that you would demand from me?
og_response: My liberty.

translated_dialog: Some dungeon.
og_response: Your bedchamber.

translated_dialog: I was trying to do what was right.
og_response: Help me into some house, Benvolio,    Or I shall faint. A plague o both your houses!    They have made worms meat of me. I have it,    And soundly too. Your houses!

translated_dialog: Sweet York, shut up. Listen to me, gentle liege.
og_response: Rise up, good aunt.

translated_dialog: Why have you killed your only daughter like this?
og_response: Not I; 'twas Chiron and Demetrius:They ravish'd her, and cut away her tongue;And they, 'twas they, that did her all this wrong.

translated_dialog: Well, Im basically finished. But still
og_response: [to ANTONIO]  He will be talking.

translated_dialog: And what's her story?
og_response: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,    But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,    Feed on her damask cheek.   She pined in thought,    And with a green and yellow melancholy    She sat like patience on a monument,    Smiling at grief.   Was not this love indeed?    We men may say more, swear more, but indeed    Our shows are more than will,   for still we prove    Much in our vows, but little in our love.

translated_dialog: What if a man were to bring him a couple hundred pounds to have fun with?
og_response: [as VINCENTIO]  Keep your hundred pounds to yourself. Heshall need none so long as I live.

translated_dialog: I don't want any halves. I'll bear it all myself.
og_response: How now, what news?

translated_dialog: I admit to two sleeves.
og_response: [reads]  The sleeves curiously cut.

translated_dialog: Your request is perfectly reasonable. In Apollo's name, bring forth the oracle.
og_response: The Emperor of Russia was my father:O that he were alive, and here beholdingHis daughter's trial! that he did but seeThe flatness of my misery, yet with eyesOf pity, not revenge!

translated_dialog: Did you call, sir?
og_response: Thaliard,    You are of our chamber, and our mind partakes    Her private actions to your secrecy;    And for your faithfulness we will advance you.    Thaliard, behold, here's poison, and here's gold;    We hate the prince of Tyre, and thou must kill him:    It fits thee not to ask the reason why,    Because we bid it. Say, is it done?

translated_dialog: What do you know?
og_response: Too well what love women to men may owe.    In faith, they are as true of heart as we.    My father had a daughter loved a man    As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,    I should your lordship.

translated_dialog: Oh, my God!
og_response: Mark his condition and the event. Then tell meIf this might be a brother.

translated_dialog: Oh, my lord, banish me, but do not kill me.
og_response: Down, strumpet!

translated_dialog: With Rosaline, my holy father? No, I have forgotten her and the sadness she gave me.
og_response: Thats my good son. But where hast thou been, then?

translated_dialog: Now my friend Petruchio will do me a favor, and present medisguised in somber robesto Baptista as a teacher, well-versed in music, to instruct Bianca. With this disguise, I'll at least have time and permission to be with Bianca alone, and then I can court her once more.
og_response: Heres no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together!

translated_dialog: I'm not tall enough to look like a real priest, nor skinny enough to look like a good student, but if you're known as an honest man and a good neighbor, then that's just as good as being dutiful and intelligent. Now here come my associates.
og_response: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

translated_dialog: I'm your friend Timon. I feel for you.
og_response: How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?I had rather be alone.

translated_dialog: Don't come back, and instead tell all of Athens that Timon has built his house on the shore, and everyday will cover himself with the surging foam of the sea. Tell them to come here and let my grave-stone be their guide. Oh lips, let these harsh words fall from you and be your last, let everything wrong with the world be healed by ravaging diseases! Graves are just another of men's works, and death another of their benefits! Go away, sun! Timon has finished his time on earth.
og_response: His discontents are unremoveablyCoupled to nature.

translated_dialog: "If?" You protector of that damned whore, are you talking to me about "ifs?" You are a traitor. Off with his head. By Saint Paul, I swear I won't eat until I see him dead.
og_response: Woe, woe for England! Not a whit for me,    For I, too fond, might have prevented this.    Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm,    And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.    Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble,    And started when he looked upon the Tower,    As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.    O, now I need the priest that spake to me!    I now repent I told the pursuivant,    As too triumphing, how mine enemies    Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered,    And I myself secure in grace and favor.    O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse    Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.

translated_dialog: She was as unfaithful as water is inconstant.
og_response: Thou art rash as fire,To say that she was false. Oh, she was heavenly true!

translated_dialog: She will not.
og_response: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

translated_dialog: Yes.
og_response: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thouhast feigned him a worthy fellow.

translated_dialog: He does indeed seem like a natural-born fooland besides being a fool, he's argumentative. If he didn't have the coward's gift of stepping away from a fight, they say he would've been long dead by now.
og_response: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors thatsay so of him. Who are they?

translated_dialog: Get her, widow!
og_response: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

translated_dialog: That's very important. Since this is what you want, sir, and I am sworn to obey youfor that's what your father commanded me when we left, saying, "Serve my son," although I don't think he had this in mindI will pretend to be Lucentio, because I love the real Lucentio so much.
og_response: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves,And let me be a slave t'achieve that maidWhose sudden sight hath thralled my wounded eye.

translated_dialog: Ah, I was your noble husband's mother, so I have just as large a share in your grief. I've already wept over my own worthy husband's death and kept myself alive only by looking at his sons, his mirror images. But now two of those mirrors have been cracked into pieces by death, and the only one left to comfort me is Richardan untrustworthy mirror who only causes me shame and grief. You are a widow, but you're also a mother, and you still have the comfort of your children left. But death has snatched my husband from my arms and then plucked my two crutches, Clarence and Edward, from my feeble hands. Oh, I have every reason to surpass you in sorrow and drown out your weeping with my own, as your loss is only half of mine!
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  Ah, aunt, you wept not for our fathers death.How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

translated_dialog: Youll find me happy to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.
og_response: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

translated_dialog: All right.
og_response: And most chirurgeonly.

translated_dialog: If it's not enough, it's still worth more than all of you, because you serve bad men.
og_response: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?

translated_dialog: Hey, guys, I like you a lot. I'll give you some gold, and in return you may rid the world of some evil men. Hang them, stab them, drown them in a toilet, I don't care. Get rid of them some way, and then come to me and I'll give you even more gold.
og_response: Name them, my lord, let's know them.

translated_dialog: [As LUCENTIO] You're a fine fellow. Here, have a drink on me.
og_response: Here comes Baptista. Set your countenance, sir.

translated_dialog: Timon, I feel so bad that I had no money left to give you when you asked me.
og_response: Think not on 't, sir.

translated_dialog: Your bedroom.
og_response: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

translated_dialog: Close to nine.
og_response: So much?

translated_dialog: Useless! The man's heroism at the battles of Lacedaemon and Byzantium should be enough to win him his life.
og_response: What's that?

translated_dialog: Well, then my pump is covered in flowers.
og_response: Sure wit, follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may remain, after the wearing solely singular.

translated_dialog: Lucius, I will.
og_response: How now, Lavinia! Marcus, what means this?    Some book there is that she desires to see.    Which is it, girl, of these? Open them, boy.    But thou art deeper read, and better skill'd    Come, and take choice of all my library,    And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens    Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.    Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?

translated_dialog: Oh, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse.
og_response: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.

translated_dialog: Come, come, Lavinia; see, your enemies are in chains. Men, stop them from talking, I dont want to hear it. But I want them to hear every word I say. Oh villains, Chiron and Demetrius! Here is the fountain youve stained with mud, the lovely summer youve mixed with your winter. You killed her husband, and for that vile crime two of her brothers were condemned to death, and my hand was cut off and made into a joke. You cut off her sweet hands and her tongue. And worse than that, inhuman traitors, you took something from her more precious than hands or tongueyou raped her. What would you say, if I let you speak? Villains, youd be ashamed to beg for mercy. Listen, miserable criminals! This is how I mean to kill you. I still have one hand left to cut your throats, while Lavinia holds between her stumps the basin that will receive your guilty blood. You know that your mother means to dine with me, and calls herself Revenge, and thinks that Im crazy. Listen, villains! Ill grind your bones to dust, and with your blood and that dust Ill make a paste, and of that paste Ill make two pies out of your shameful heads. And then Ill tell that whore, your unholy mother, to eat you and swallow her own children. This is the feast Ive prepared for her, and this is the food shell eat. For you treated my daughter worse than Philomel, and Ill be revenged worse than Progne. And now prepare your throats. Lavinia, come,
og_response: Receive the blood: and when that they are dead,    Let me go grind their bones to powder small    And with this hateful liquor temper it;    And in that paste let their vile heads be baked.    Come, come, be every one officious    To make this banquet;   which I wish may prove    More stern and bloody than the Centaurs' feast.    So, now bring them in, for I'll play the cook,    And see them ready 'gainst their mother comes.

translated_dialog: The darkness of night masks my face, or else youd see me blushing about the things you heard me say tonight. I would gladly stick to the proper manners of courtship and deny everything I said. But, instead: I'll say goodbye to good manners! Do you love me? I know you will answer yes, and I will trust you. But your swears may turn out to be false. They say that Jove laughs when lovers lie. Oh, noble Romeo, if you really love me, say it in truth. Or if you think Im letting myself be won too easily, then Ill frown and act superior and unapproachable so that youll woo me. But if thats not necessary, then I would never act that way. In truth, beautiful Montague, I like you too much, which might make it seem as if I am overly silly and flirtatious. But trust me, gentleman, Ill prove to be more faithful than girls who act coy and standoffish. I probably should have acted more standoffish, I confess, but you overheard me talking about my passion for you before I knew you were there. So please forgive me, and dont condemn me for so quickly falling in love when it was only revealed to you because the dark night let you discover it.
og_response: Lady, by yonder blessèd moon I vow,That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops

translated_dialog: And if I dont, may my hands rot off and never wield a sword again!
og_response: I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle;    And spur thee on with full as many lies    As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear    From sun to sun:   there is my honour's pawn;    Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

translated_dialog: I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman.
og_response: Get you to your lord.    I cannot love him. Let him send no more    Unless perchance you come to me again    To tell me how he takes it.   Fare you well.    I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.

translated_dialog: By the future.
og_response: That thou hast wrongèd in the time o'erpast;    For I myself have many tears to wash    Hereafter time, for time past wronged by thee.    The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered,    Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age;    The parents live whose children thou hast butchered,    Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.    Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast    Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.

translated_dialog: Good, good.
og_response: [sings]    What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.    Present mirth hath present laughter.    Whats to come is still unsure.    In delay there lies no plenty.    Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.    Youths a stuff will not endure.

translated_dialog: And I agree.
og_response: Then be it so, and go we to determine    Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.    Madam, and you, my sister, will you go    To give your censures in this business?

translated_dialog: From my heart and my soul too. If not, curse them both.
og_response: Amen!

translated_dialog: [Reading] "The sleeves elaborately cut."
og_response: Ay, theres the villany.

translated_dialog: As for me: rest assured I had no bad intentions. Actually, this whole place is disgusting. Goodbye. You are virtuous, and I have no doubt that you've had an aristocratic education. Here, here's more gold for you. Curse anyone who tries to force himself on you, may he die like a thief! If you ever hear from me again, it'll be for your benefit.
og_response: I beseech your honour, one piece for me.

translated_dialog: [Drawing his sword] Draw your sword, Benvolio, and help me beat down their weapons. Gentlemen, this is shameful. Tybalt! Mercutio! The Prince has explicitly forbidden fighting in the streets of Verona. Stop! Tybalt! Good Mercutio!
og_response: Away, Tybalt.

translated_dialog: You, sir? Why, who are you?
og_response: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do moreThan you have heard him brag to you he will.

translated_dialog: This gentleman Lucilius has served me for a long time. I will make some efforts to build his fortune, such is the duty of friendship. If you give him your daughter I will match whatever you give and make him her equal.
og_response: Most noble lord,Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

translated_dialog: The rest of you can leave too.
og_response: Once more, Cesario,    Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.    Tell her my love, more noble than the world,    Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;    The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her,    Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;    But tis that miracle and queen of gems    That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

translated_dialog: Then, what does she think when I speak about love and peace?
og_response: [Aside]  But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

translated_dialog: What is that music? My good friends, listen!
og_response: Marvelous sweet music!

translated_dialog: Bid me farewell.
og_response: 'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you,Imagine I have said farewell already.

translated_dialog: No, never.
og_response: So long could IStand by, a looker on.

translated_dialog: Kind uncle York, the latest news is that the rebels have set the town of Cicester in Gloucestershire on fire; but we don't know whether they've been captured or killed.
og_response: Welcome, my lord what is the news?

translated_dialog: The commons won't be satisfied, then.
og_response: They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough,When I do see the very book indeedWhere all my sins are writ, and that's myself.

translated_dialog: They will be satisfied: Ill read from the book where all my sins are writtenmyself.
og_response: Give me the glass, and therein will I read.    No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck    So many blows upon this face of mine,    And made no deeper wounds?   O flattering glass,    Like to my followers in prosperity,    Thou dost beguile me!   Was this face the face    That every day under his household roof    Did keep ten thousand men?   was this the face    That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?    Was this the face that faced so many follies,    And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?    A brittle glory shineth in this face:    As brittle as the glory is the face;

translated_dialog: But I will bury them in your daughter's womb, and in that nest of fragrant spices they will be reborn again, to grow and comfort you.
og_response: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

translated_dialog: Grandfather, it's Ovid's Metamorphoses; my mother gave it to me.
og_response: For love of her that's gone,Perhaps she cull'd it from among the rest.

translated_dialog: For what?
og_response: For your broken shin.

translated_dialog: What are you doing there? Speak up.
og_response: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,For showing me again the eyes of man!

translated_dialog: Listen closely and do exactly what I tell you. If you fail at any point, it means death for not only you, but for your horrible wife (who, at least for now, I forgive). I command you as my subject to carry this bastard to some deserted place far away from this country. Leave it there, to the mercy of the elements. It appeared in my life by a stroke of bad luck. Therefore, I command that you, on pain of damnation and death, leave it up to luck whether it lives or dies. Now pick it up.
og_response: I swear to do this, though a present death    Had been more merciful.   Come on, poor babe:    Some powerful spirit instruct the kites and ravens    To be thy nurses! Wolves and bears, they say    Casting their savageness aside have done    Like offices of pity.   Sir, be prosperous    In more than this deed does require!   And blessing    Against this cruelty fight on thy side,    Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!

translated_dialog: Because I think that she loved you as well as you love your lady Silvia. She dreams of the man who has forgotten her love. You are obsessed with someone who doesn't care to have your love. It's a pity that love should be so contrary. And thinking of it makes me cry, "Ah!"
og_response: Well, give her that ring and therewithal    This letter. That's her chamber.   Tell my lady    I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.    Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,    Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

translated_dialog: Do you hear, Biondello
og_response: I cannot tarry. I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit,and so may you, sir.   And so adieu, sir.   My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Lukes to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.

translated_dialog: What, a drum? So soon? [Talking to some of the gold] I'll bury you: you will walk about again when your keeper cannot stand because of his gout. Actually, no, stay out here for leverage.

translated_dialog: What do you think of this change?
og_response: This cannot be,    By no assay of reason. 'Tis a pageant,    To keep us in false gaze.   When we consider    Th' importancy of Cyprus to the Turk,    And let ourselves again but understand    That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes    So may he with more facile question bear it,    For that it stands not in such warlike brace    But altogether lacks th' abilities    That Rhodes is dressed in.   If we make thought of this    We must not think the Turk is so unskillful    To leave that latest which concerns him first,    Neglecting an attempt of ease and gain    To wake and wage a danger profitless.

translated_dialog: There is hope for the country under his rule, though. A young king who governs wisely under his advisors will govern wisely on his own when he reaches adulthood.
og_response: So stood the state when Henry the SixthWas crowned in Paris but at nine months old.

translated_dialog: [To a SERVINGMAN] Who is that girl on the arm of that man over there?
og_response: I know not, sir.

translated_dialog: By the Virgin Mary, Id swear thirty years.
og_response: What, man, tis not so much, tis not so much.    Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,    Come Pentecost as quickly as it will,    Some five and twenty years, and then we masked.

translated_dialog: [Disguising his voice] What's going on, I say! Quiet in this prison!
og_response: The knave counterfeits well. A good knave.

translated_dialog: The only profit I seek is a quiet, peaceful match.
og_response: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.    But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.    Now is the day we long have lookèd for.    I am your neighbor, and was suitor first.

translated_dialog: In that the king is condemned by everyone.
og_response: If judgement lie in them, then so do we,Because we ever have been near the king.

translated_dialog: Antonio, I arrest you on the orders of Duke Orsino.
og_response: You do mistake me, sir.

translated_dialog: There is good hope, madam. The king seems cheerful.
og_response: God grant him health. Did you confer with him?

translated_dialog: No, my precious darling, Id rather tear my muscles and break my back than let you do such dishonorable work while I sit lazily nearby.
og_response: It would become me    As well as it does you,   and I should do it    With much more ease, for my good will is to it    And yours it is against.

translated_dialog: If you assumed this disposition to punish yourself for our pride, that was a good idea. But you are forcing it! If you weren't a beggar, you could be a courtier again. Willful poverty is safer than uncertain luxury, and achieves what it wants sooner. One is always seeking more and never fulfilled. The other will accept no better situation, but has a crazy and miserable existence and is happy with the worst of the worst. You should kill yourself, as miserable as you are.
og_response: Not by his breath that is more miserable.    Thou art a slave, whom Fortune's tender arm    With favour never clasp'd; but bred a dog.    Hadst thou, like us from our first swath, proceeded    The sweet degrees that this brief world affords    To such as may the passive drugs of it    Freely command, thou wouldst have plunged thyself    In general riot; melted down thy youth    In different beds of lust;   and never learn'd    The icy precepts of respect, but follow'd    The sugar'd game before thee.   But myself,    Who had the world as my confectionary,    The mouths, the tongues, the eyes and hearts of men    At duty, more than I could frame employment,    That numberless upon me stuck as leaves    Do on the oak, hive with one winter's brush    Fell from their boughs and left me open, bare    For every storm that blows:   I, to bear this,    That never knew but better, is some burden:    Thy nature did commence in sufferance, time    Hath made thee hard in't. Why shouldst thou hate men?    They never flatter'd thee: what hast thou given?    If thou wilt curse, thy father, that poor rag,    Must be thy subject, who in spite put stuff    To some she beggar and compounded thee    Poor rogue hereditary.   Hence, be gone!    If thou hadst not been born the worst of men,    Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.

translated_dialog: My lord
og_response: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

translated_dialog: I hope your business destroys youthat is, if the gods don't first!
og_response: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

translated_dialog: Don't worry about it.
og_response: My noble lord,

translated_dialog: A sword is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
og_response: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

translated_dialog: Here is the receipt for debts you owe me.
og_response: Here's mine.

translated_dialog: Gentlemen, go on to the bridal dinner. I see that a woman will be made into a fool if she doesn't stand up for herself.
og_response: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.    Obey the bride, you that attend on her.    Go to the feast, revel and domineer,    Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,    Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves.    But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.    Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret;    I will be master of what is mine own.    She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house,    My household stuff, my field, my barn,    My horse, my ox, my ass, my anything.    And here she stands, touch her whoever dare.    Ill bring mine action on the proudest he    That stops my way in Padua.   Grumio,    Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves.    Rescue thy mistress if thou be a man.    Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate.    Ill buckler thee against a million.

translated_dialog: Dear lady, why are you in mourning?
og_response: Good fool, for my brothers death.

translated_dialog: Oh Godof whose side I call myself captainplease look upon my forces with a gracious eye. Put the bruising swords of anger in their hands, so they can crush the helmets of our enemies! Make us agents of your divine punishment, so we can praise you when we're victorious! I entrust my soul to you now, before I close my eyes and fall asleep. Oh God, defend me always, whether sleeping or waking! [He falls asleep]
og_response: [to RICHARD]    Let me sit heavy on thy soul tomorrow!    Think how thou stabbedst me in my prime of youth    At Tewkesbury. Despair therefore, and die!     [to RICHMOND]     Be cheerful, Richmond, for the wrongèd souls    Of butchered princes fight in thy behalf.    King Henrys issue, Richmond, comforts thee.

translated_dialog: If you continue to complain, Ill split an oak tree and lock you inside its wooden trunk until youve howled for twelve years.
og_response: Pardon, master.I will be correspondent to commandAnd do my spiriting gently.

translated_dialog: I can't say.
og_response: A sickness caught of me, and yet I well!    I must be answer'd.   Dost thou hear, Camillo,    I conjure thee, by all the parts of man    Which honour does acknowledge, whereof the least    Is not this suit of mine, that thou declare    What incidency thou dost guess of harm    Is creeping toward me;   how far off, how near;    Which way to be prevented, if to be;    If not, how best to bear it.

translated_dialog: Calm down, no one here is going to steal from you. However, we would like to trade you for your poor man's clothes, so get undressed (it's necessary, you see) and change clothes with this gentleman. Though Florizel's getting the worst end of the deal already, we'll give you some money, too.
og_response: I am a poor fellow, sir.  [Aside]  I know ye well enough.

translated_dialog: Call them in.
og_response: [calling offstage]  Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to countenance my mistress.

translated_dialog: If only you were, sir.
og_response: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady.   It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.

translated_dialog: Why have you not proclaimed Northumberland and all the rest of the rebels as traitors?
og_response: We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester    Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship,    And all the household servants fled with him    To Bolingbroke.

translated_dialog: Could I speak with you a moment, your honor? It is urgent.
og_response: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:I prithee, let's be provided to show thementertainment.

translated_dialog: Oh, curse those evil people! It was a person like this who got inside your head and made you suspect that I cheated on you with the Moor.
og_response: You are a fool. Go to.

translated_dialog: Who could say that I'm a villain, when I give free and honest advice that is helpful for Cassio in winning back the Moor's favor? For it really is easy to persuade Desdemona to help you in anything. She gives rise to as many good things as nature itself. And Othello is such a slave to his love for her that he would renounce his baptism and reject all symbols of Christian redemption to win her over. She can do whatever she wants, and whatever she desires he will carry out. How then could I be a villain, when I am advising Cassio to do what is in his best interest? That's Satan's theology! When devils do the worst sins, they first put on the pretense of goodness and innocence, as I am doing now. For while this honest fool begs Desdemona to fix his misfortune and while she pleads on his behalf to the Moor, I'll poison Othello's thoughts by whispering into his ear. I'll say that Desdemona is standing up for Cassio because she is attracted to him. The more that she argues for Cassio, the guiltier she'll seem to the Moor. In this way I'll turn her own virtue into a sort of tar, to entrap herand everyone elsewith her own goodness.
og_response: How now, Roderigo!

translated_dialog: Sir, I didn't do anything. These gentlemen are my friends and can vouch for me.
og_response: We can: my royal liege,He is not guilty of her coming hither.

translated_dialog: Anything.
og_response: Do not desire to see this letter.

translated_dialog: Come on, buddy!
og_response: Ha, come and bring away the nets!

translated_dialog: Norfolk, there's a worse sentence for you, which I say with some regret: the slow hours will not bring you any closer to ending your banishment, for I order you never to return, upon pain of death.
og_response: A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege,    And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth:    A dearer merit, not so deep a maim    As to be cast forth in the common air,    Have I deserved at your highness' hands.    The language I have learn'd these forty years,    My native English, now I must forego:    And now my tongue's use is to me no more    Than an unstringed viol or a harp,    Or like a cunning instrument cased up,    Or, being open, put into his hands    That knows no touch to tune the harmony:    Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue,    Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips;    And dull unfeeling barren ignorance    Is made my gaoler to attend on me.    I am too old to fawn upon a nurse,    Too far in years to be a pupil now:    What is thy sentence then but speechless death,    Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath?

translated_dialog: It looks like food for kings.
og_response: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yieldit.

translated_dialog: I swear by my own hand, I am. Good fool, bring me some ink, paper, and light, and then deliver the letter I'll write to my lady. You'll be better rewarded for delivering this letter than you've ever been rewarded before.
og_response: I will help you to t. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed? Or do you but counterfeit?

translated_dialog: Well, I can cut a caper.
og_response: And I can cut the mutton to t.

translated_dialog: Groan?! Why, of course not. Just tell me who it is.
og_response: A sick man in sadness makes his will,A word ill urged to one that is so ill. In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

translated_dialog: Oh my friends, I wanted to say one thing to you. You, my good lord, I must beg youpleaseto honor me by taking this jewel. Accept it and wear it kindly, my lord.
og_response: I am so far already in your gifts,

translated_dialog: Now the winter of our troubles has been transformed into glorious summer by the ascension of my brother, King Edward IV, son of the house of York. All the clouds that had descended over our family have now been banished and returned to the sea. Now we wear wreaths of victory on our foreheads, and we've hung up our armor as decoration. We've exchanged the sound of our battle trumpets for the sound of joyful greetings, and our death marches have become stately dances. The grim, warlike expressions on our faces have smoothed. And instead of charging on armored horses to frighten our opponents, we now dance in ladies' chambers to seductive songs on the lute. But as for me, I am not made for such games of love, or to admire myself in a mirror. I was badly made, and I lack the good looks to strut in front of passing girls. Nature has cheated me out of handsome features and proper proportions. I was born deformed, unfinished, and born prematurely. I was barely half-created when I came into the world, and left so lame and misshapen that dogs bark at me as I limp past them. In such delicate times of peace, I have nothing to do. No joys help me pass the time, unless I want to see my own shadow in the sun and make speeches about my deformity. Therefore, since I cannot amuse myself by being a lover during these peaceful days, I am determined to become a villain. I have hatched plots and put dangerous plans into action, using prophecies made while drunk; slander; and stories about dreams in order to set my brother George, Duke of Clarence, against my other brother, the king, so that they hate each other. If King Edward is as true as I am clever, false, and treacherous, then this very day Clarence will be imprisoned because of a prophecy that "G" will murder Edward's children. But, you thoughts, hide yourselves deep down in my soul, for here comes Clarence.
og_response: Brother, good day. What means this armèd guardThat waits upon your Grace?

translated_dialog: Come, sir, you rudely threw it to her, and she wants it to be returned just as rudely. [he throws down the ring] If it's worth stooping to pick up, there it is where you can see it. If not, let whoever finds it first have it.
og_response: I left no ring with her. What means this lady?    Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!    She made good view of me, indeed so much    That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,    For she did speak in starts distractedly.    She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion    Invites me in this churlish messenger.    None of my lords ring? Why, he sent her none.    I am the man.   If it be so, as tis,    Poor lady, she were better love a dream.    Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness,    Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.    How easy is it for the proper false    In womens waxen hearts to set their forms!    Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we,    For such as we are made of, such we be.    How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly,    And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,    And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.    What will become of this? As I am man,    My state is desperate for my masters love.    As I am woman, now, alas the day,    What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!    O time, thou must untangle this, not I.    It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

og_response: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.

translated_dialog: I am a friend who knows you well.
og_response: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,    What torch is yond that vainly lends his light    To grubs and eyeless skulls?   As I discern,    It burneth in the Capels monument.

translated_dialog: Yes, sir, we are part of her entourage.
og_response: I know thee well. How dost thou, my good fellow?

translated_dialog: [To FERDINAND] If Ive been too strict in my punishment of you, your compensation will make it better. For I am giving you my daughter, who makes up a third of my entire life, and who is everything I live for. I put her into your hands. All of the trouble I gave you was just my way of testing your love for her, and you have endured those tests extraordinarily well. Here, before God, I promise you that I will give you this precious gift. Oh, Ferdinand, dont laugh at me for praising her so highly, because youll discover that she exceeds all the praise given to her.
og_response: I do believe itAgainst an oracle.

translated_dialog: Is it afternoon?
og_response: Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.

translated_dialog: [To VIOLA] There's nothing to be done, sir; he still wants to fight you just because he swore that he would. But he's reconsidered his reasons for challenging you, and now realizes that they're so insignificant that they're not worth discussing. So draw your sword so that he can fulfill his promise. He promises he won't hurt you.
og_response: [aside]  Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

translated_dialog: That makes sensesomeone rich enough to ride a horse wouldn't have been wearing rags like this. Give me your hand, I'll help you up. Give me your hand.  [He grasps AUTOLYCUS's hand and pulls]
og_response: O, good sir, tenderly, O!

translated_dialog: A singing, drunken monster.
og_response: [sings]      No more dams Ill make for fish,    Nor fetch in firing    At requiring,    Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish.    'Ban, 'Ban, Ca-Caliban    Has a new master. Get a new man.    Freedom, high-day! High-day, freedom! Freedom, high-day, freedom!

translated_dialog: What do you remember? Some house or person? Tell me about anything you see in your memory.
og_response: 'Tis far off,    And rather like a dream than an assurance    That my remembrance warrants.   Had I not    Four or five women once that tended me?

translated_dialog: How are you, General? Have you hurt your head?
og_response: Dost thou mock me?

translated_dialog: Yes, or just try to hide and suppress the lie.
og_response: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the kings fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

translated_dialog: God have mercy, Grumio! Then he'll have no chance.
og_response: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

translated_dialog: Youre wrong there. I would have made it short. I had come to the full depth of my tale, and intended to say nothing more about it.
og_response: Heres goodly gear.

translated_dialog: Bless you, daughter!
og_response: Hail, madam, and my queen!

translated_dialog: It shall not live.
og_response: It shall not die.

translated_dialog: Fool, fool, fool, I say!
og_response: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you sir? I am shent forspeaking to you.

translated_dialog: My holy lady, these are two flaws that some alcohol and good advice will fix. If you give the dry fool a drink, then the fool won't be dry anymore. And if you give the unreliable man some good advice, then he can mend his ways and won't be unreliable anymore. And if he can't mend his ways, then let the tailor mend him. Anything that's mended is only patched up. A virtuous man who does something wrong is only patched with sin, and a sinner who mends his ways is only patched with virtue. If this logical argument will convince you, then good. But if not, what can be done? The only truly betrayed husband is one deserted by luck, and beauty is a lucky flowerso you won't remain alone for long, my lady. But you gave orders to take away the fool. So I tell you all again, take the lady away.
og_response: Sir, I bade them take away you.

translated_dialog: When he stands where I am and sees you there.
og_response: [as LUCENTIO]  But say, what to thine old news?

translated_dialog: Oh no, you scorn me! I've been tricked!
og_response: Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?

translated_dialog: You speak the truth. Proud Bolingbroke, I come to fight with you for our day of doom. This fit of fear was overblown; winning will be an easy task, since we're winning what belongs to us. Tell us, Scroop, where is our uncle with his army? Speak sweetly, man, although your looks are sour.
og_response: Men judge by the complexion of the sky    The state and inclination of the day:    So may you by my dull and heavy eye,    My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.    I play the torturer, by small and small    To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:    Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke,    And all your northern castles yielded up,    And all your southern gentlemen in arms    Upon his party.

translated_dialog: And what should I do in Illyria? My brother is in Heaven. Or perhaps there's a chance he didn't drown. What do you think, sailors?
og_response: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

translated_dialog: Men look at the sky and see what sort of a day it will be; so you can guess, by my sad and tearful eyes, that my tongue has another heavy tale to say. I'm like a torturer, telling you all the bad news in small parts. Your uncle York has allied with Bolingbroke, giving up all your northern castles and all your southern army to him.
og_response: Thou hast said enough.    Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth    Of that sweet way I was in to despair!    What say you now? what comfort have we now?    By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly    That bids me be of comfort any more.    Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;    A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey.    That power I have, discharge; and let them go    To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,    For I have none:   let no man speak again    To alter this, for counsel is but vain.

translated_dialog: Then Ill take my serving knife to smack you upside the head. I wont need to sing. Ill make you sing. Do you hear me?
og_response: An you re us and fa us, you note us.

translated_dialog: You taught me language, and all I gained from it is that I now know how to curse. May you die of the plague for teaching me your language!
og_response: Hag-seed, hence!    Fetch us in fuel. And be quick, thou 'rt best,    To answer other business. Shrugst thou, malice?    If thou neglectst or dost unwillingly    What I command, Ill rack thee with old cramps,    Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar    That beasts shall tremble at thy din.

translated_dialog: Search the market carefully. Mytilene is full of young men. We lost too much money this season because we didn't have enough girls.
og_response: We were never so much out of creatures.   We have but    poor three, and they can do no more than they can    do;   and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.

translated_dialog: [As LUCENTIO] Then let's go to my lodging, if you'd like. That's where my father is staying, and tonight we can complete our transactions privately there. Send your servant for Bianca. My boy will fetch the notary right away. The only bad thing is that with such short notice, we'll only be able to offer you a small meal.
og_response: It likes me well.   Cambio, hie you home,    And bid Bianca make her ready straight.    And, if you will, tell what hath happenèd:    Lucentios father is arrived in Padua,    And how shes like to be Lucentios wife.

translated_dialog: Will I forget to be who I am?
og_response: Ay, if your selfs remembrance wrong yourself.

translated_dialog: [Handing OLIVIA a paper] Lady, you have. Please look at that letter. You can't deny that it's in your handwriting. Try to write differently if you can, or try to say that that isn't your seal, with your design on ityou can't deny any of this. Well, admit it then and tell me, with the sincerity of an honorable person, why you gave me such clear signs of affection, telling me to come to you smiling, with crossed laces, to wear yellow stockings, and to be rude to Sir Toby and the servants? And when I obeyed all your commands, why did you then let me be imprisoned in a dark house, be visited by a priestand make me into the biggest fool and sucker that ever had a joke played on him? Tell me why.
og_response: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,    Though, I confess, much like the character.    But out of question, tis Marias hand.    And now I do bethink me, it was she    First told me thou wast mad, then camest in smiling,    And in such forms which here were presupposed    Upon thee in the letter.   Prithee, be content.    This practice hath most shrewdly passed upon thee;    But when we know the grounds and authors of it,    Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge    Of thine own cause.

translated_dialog: Good night, honest Iago.
og_response: And whats he then that says I play the villain?    When this advice is free I give and honest,    Probal to thinking and indeed the course    To win the Moor again?   For tis most easy    Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue    In any honest suit. Shes framed as fruitful    As the free elements.   And then for her    To win the Moor, were to renounce his baptism,    All seals and symbols of redeemèd sin,    His soul is so enfettered to her love,    That she may make, unmake, do what she list,    Even as her appetite shall play the god    With his weak function. How am I then a villain    To counsel Cassio to this parallel course,    Directly to his good? Divinity of hell!    When devils will the blackest sins put on    They do suggest at first with heavenly shows    As I do now.   For whiles this honest fool    Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune    And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,    Ill pour this pestilence into his ear:    That she repeals him for her bodys lust.    And by how much she strives to do him good    She shall undo her credit with the Moor.    So will I turn her virtue into pitch    And out of her own goodness make the net    That shall enmesh them all.

translated_dialog: Thank you. Sailor, where are we?
og_response: We are near Tarsus.
(  aside  ) Peace, peace!

translated_dialog: Where is noble Rivers, and Vaughan, and Grey?
og_response: Where is kind Hastings?

translated_dialog: Here in your city; I just came from him. And (it may seem crazy . . . I can hardly believe it myself) while Polixenes was on his way to your court, chasing this young couple, he ran into this girl's father and brother, who have also fled the country.
og_response: Camillo has betray'd me;Whose honour and whose honesty till nowEndured all weathers.

translated_dialog: I couldn't agree with you more; I have high expectations for him. He's a great kidlike chicken soup for the soul, he keeps us old folks young. The Sicilians who were old and in wheelchairs before he was even born are hoping they live to see him grow up.
og_response: Would they else be content to die?

translated_dialog: Please, speak. You can't tell a lie; you look like the embodiment of Justice, like the queen of Truth. I will believe you, even if you say things that seem impossible, because you look like someone I used to love. Who was your family? Didn't you say, when I pushed you back, when I first looked at you, that you came from a good family?
og_response: So indeed I did.

translated_dialog: The king has the face of someone who's just lost a much-loved territory in wartime. Just now I saw him and greeted him as always. He looked down at the floor, muttered to himself, and ran away, leaving me wondering what's going on that would so totally change his behavior.
og_response: I dare not know, my lord.

translated_dialog: [To FERDINAND] Sweet lord, youre cheating.
og_response: No, my dearest love,I would not for the world.

translated_dialog: Did you call, sir?
og_response: Thou art a grave and noble counsellor,    Most wise in general:   tell me, if thou canst,    What this maid is, or what is like to be,    That thus hath made me weep?

translated_dialog: What a bloody conclusion!
og_response: All that is spoke is marred.

translated_dialog: Whichever way this goes, I live or die a loyal, just, and honest gentleman true to King Richard's throne. A captive never escaped slavery with more happiness than my dancing soul feels at the prospect of doing battle with my enemy.  Most mighty liege, and my fellow nobles, I wish you all many happy years: I go to fight as peacefully and happily as if I were just heading out to play a game, for honesty sets the heart at ease.
og_response: Farewell, my lord: securely I espyVirtue with valour couched in thine eye.Order the trial, marshal, and begin.

translated_dialog: In God's name, who are you?
og_response: A man, as you are.

translated_dialog: Well, but what time is it?
og_response: Upon the stroke of ten.

translated_dialog: The wind is good to send messages to Ireland, but we've heard nothing back. We can't raise an army the size of Bolingbroke's.
og_response: Besides, our nearness to the king in loveIs near the hate of those love not the king.

translated_dialog: Who shall stop me? I will despair, and be an enemy to false hope: he is a flatterer, a parasite, and a keeper back of deathdeath, which would let us end our lives gently, when hope makes up live on and suffer.
og_response: Here comes the Duke of York.

translated_dialog: Im weary. Give me some time alone. Oh, my bones are aching! What a journey this has been today.
og_response: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.Nay, come, I pray thee, speak. Good, good Nurse, speak.

translated_dialog: You speak too bitterly.
og_response: Hear me a word,For I shall never speak to thee again.

translated_dialog: [To himself] And as his moneybags will prove.
og_response: Gremio, tis now no time to vent our love.    Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,    Ill tell you news indifferent good for either.    [presenting  PETRUCHIO  ]    Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,    Upon agreement from us to his liking,    Will undertake to woo curst Katherine,    Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

translated_dialog: Lean close and I'll tell you.
og_response: Here.

translated_dialog: Don't be afraid, my lord; God, who made you king, has the power to keep you king in spite of everything. We should make use of what heaven gives us, not ignore it; otherwise, by refusing His help, we're disobeying God's will.
og_response: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss;    Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security,    Grows strong and great in substance and in power.

translated_dialog: Madam, I'll leave now.
og_response: Why, stay and hear me speak.

translated_dialog: Then we'll do that. Now let's go and figure out which of us will ride off to Ludlow.
og_response: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince,    For Gods sake let not us two at home.    For by the way Ill sort occasion,    As index to the story we late talked of,    To part the queens proud kindred from the prince.

translated_dialog: How is this possible?
og_response: [To ANTONIO]  When came he to this town?

translated_dialog: [To herself] Hes far from a villain.
og_response: That is because the traitor murderer lives.

translated_dialog: Thank you! You're so generous.
og_response: Who have we here?  [Seeing AUTOLYCUS]  We'll make an instrument of this, omitNothing may give us aid.

translated_dialog: I'll swear to do this, though it would have been more merciful to just kill it. [To the baby] Come on, poor baby. May a guardian angel protect you from vicious animals. They say that wolves and bears sometimes take pity on human babies on nurse them, too.[To LEONTES] Sir, good luck to you. [To the baby] I hope you're protected from everything horrible, you poor thing, even though you're condemned to be lost.
og_response: No, I'll not rearAnother's issue.

translated_dialog: Hello, Marina! Why are you alone? Why isn't my daughter with you? Don't make yourself sick with being so upset; I'll be your nurse now. Look how your situation has changed with this unfortunate loss! Come on, give me your flowers before the sea air wilts them. Walk with Leonine down by the shore. The air will do you some good; the wind is refreshing and makes your stomach strong. Come on, Leonine; take her by the arm, walk with her.
og_response: No, I pray you;I'll not bereave you of your servant.

translated_dialog: Anything, sir, that I'm capable of doing. I'll lay down my life to save the innocent. I'll do anything that's possible.
og_response: It shall be possible. Swear by this swordThou wilt perform my bidding.

translated_dialog: Tell him I said thanks.
og_response: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

translated_dialog: Yes, Desdemona.
og_response: Will you come to bed, my lord?

translated_dialog: [To DORSET] Quiet, Master Marquess, you're being impudent. Your noble title is so newly-minted that its not even legal yet. Oh, that your recent nobility could understand what it means to be lost and miserable! Those who are very high up must be shaken by many blasts of wind. And when they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
og_response: Good counsel, marry. Learn it, learn it, marquess.

translated_dialog: Ha, ha! What are these things here that we're seeing, my lord Antonio? Can you buy them with money?
og_response: Very like. One of themIs a plain fish, and no doubt marketable.

translated_dialog: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak words can persuade his mother to give up the Duke of York, then you can expect him here soon. But if she resists my mild requests, then God forbid that we should break the holy laws of sanctuary! I would not commit such a terrible sin even in exchange for a kingdom.
og_response: You are too senseless obstinate, my lord,    Too ceremonious and traditional.    Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,    You break not sanctuary in seizing him.    The benefit thereof is always granted    To those whose dealings have deserved the place    And those who have the wit to claim the place.    This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it    And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.    Then taking him from thence that is not there,    You break no privilege nor charter there.    Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,    But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.

translated_dialog: No, sir, I'm worse.
og_response: How can that be?

translated_dialog: May God protect his Majesty!
og_response: Long live Gonzalo!

translated_dialog: Well, I'll have to rape her, or she'll ruin all our customers, converting the evil-doers to good.
og_response: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

translated_dialog: You've faced many things, haven't you?
og_response: I have.

translated_dialog: Asses are meant for bearing, and so are you.
og_response: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

translated_dialog: Im just trying to keep the peace. Put away your sword, or else use it to help me stop this fighting.
og_response: What, drawn, and talk of peace? I hate the word,As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.Have at thee, coward!

translated_dialog: No, boy, not that; Ill teach you another way. Lavinia, come. Marcus, take care of my house while Im gone; Lucius and I will go make a spectacle of ourselves at court. Yes, indeed we will, sir; and theyll pay attention.
og_response: O heavens, can you hear a good man groan,    And not relent, or not compassion him?    Marcus, attend him in his ecstasy,    That hath more scars of sorrow in his heart    Than foemen's marks upon his batter'd shield;    But yet so just that he will not revenge.    Revenge, ye heavens, for old Andronicus!

translated_dialog: Madam, Im here. What do you want?
og_response: This is the matter.Nurse, give leave awhile,    We must talk in secret.   Nurse, come back again.    I have remembered me. Thous hear our counsel.    Thou knowst my daughters of a pretty age.

translated_dialog: [Picking up the letter] By God, this is my lady's handwritingthese are her C's, her U's, and her T's, and this is how she makes her big P's. It's her handwriting, without question.
og_response: (  aside  ) Her Cs, her Us and her Ts. Why that?

translated_dialog: Let's go meet and welcome him.
og_response: Lo, where he comes!

translated_dialog: [To herself] But love won't be inspired by something it hates.
og_response: What says she to my face?

translated_dialog: I beg you, dont scold me. The one I love now returns my love. The other did not.
og_response: Oh, she knew well    Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.    But come, young waverer, come, go with me,    In one respect Ill thy assistant be,    For this alliance may so happy prove    To turn your households rancor to pure love.

translated_dialog: What must be will be.
og_response: Thats a certain text.

translated_dialog: Not to his fathers house. I asked Romeos servant.
og_response: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

translated_dialog: Be quiet, monster. Madame clothesline, isn't this my jacket? Thank you kindly. Now the jacket is under the line. Now, jacket, you'll probably lose your fur trim and become a bald jacket.
og_response: Do, do. We steal by line and level, an t like your grace.

translated_dialog: Then I do not lie.
og_response: Art not a poet?

translated_dialog: Oh, no! You're dying, although I'm the sicker one.
og_response: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

translated_dialog: I won't.
og_response: Should you do so, my lord,    My speech should fall into such vile success    Which my thoughts aimed not at.   Cassios my worthy friend    My lord, I see youre moved.

translated_dialog: Monster, use your fingers. Help to carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is, or Ill throw you out of my kingdom. Get going, carry this.
og_response: And this.

translated_dialog: The feud is between our masters and us, their servants.
og_response: Tis all one. I will show myself a tyrant. When I have fought with the men, I will be civil with the maids. I will cut off their heads.

translated_dialog: And you're not a loyal man, as we are.
og_response: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

translated_dialog: Do something for me before I come to you. I see that Rape and Murder stand by your side; to prove that you really are Revenge, stab them or crush them under the wheels of your chariot. Then Ill come and be your charioteer, and travel with you around the globe. Ill give you two black horses to pull your wagon of revenge as you find the murderers in their guilty caves; and when the cart is loaded with their heads, Ill dismount and trot alongside your wheel like a slavish footman all day long, from when the sun rises in the east until it falls into the sea. And Ill do this hard task every day, if you destroy Rape and Murder there.
og_response: These are my ministers, and come with me.

translated_dialog: Fair cousin? I must be greater than a kingfor when I was a king, my flatterers were only subjects, but now as a subject, I have a king to flatter me. Since Im so great, I suppose theres no need to beg.
og_response: Yet ask.

translated_dialog: You are as impetuous as fire to say that she was unfaithful. She was heavenly faithful and honest!
og_response: Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else.    Oh, I were damned beneath all depth in hell,    But that I did proceed upon just grounds    To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.

translated_dialog: But villain, aren't you the messenger?
og_response: Ay, of my pigeons, sir; nothing else.

translated_dialog: I am your wife, my lord. Your true and loyal wife.
og_response: Come, swear it, damn thyself.    Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves    Should fear to seize thee.   Therefore be double damned,    Swear thou art honest!

translated_dialog: Why, what do you mean by "moveable?"
og_response: A joint stool.

translated_dialog: [Singing] Alas, why is she like this?
og_response: Fool, I say!

translated_dialog: We want the money Timon owes.
og_response: Ay,    If money were as certain as your waiting,    'Twere sure enough.    Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills,    When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?    Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts    And take down the interest into their    gluttonous maws.    You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;    Let me pass quietly:    Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end;    I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

translated_dialog: Not since the time of the widow Dido.
og_response: Widow! A pox o' that! How came that widow in? Widow Dido!

translated_dialog: [Whispering] Oh, if only I had a slingshot, to shoot him in the eye!
og_response: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed, where I have left Olivia sleeping

translated_dialog: You've spoken your piece, now.
og_response: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.

translated_dialog: I did not kill your husband.
og_response: Why then, he is alive.

translated_dialog: Well, what are you?
og_response: Your wife, my lord. Your true and loyal wife.

translated_dialog: [To soldiers] Give me a goblet of wine. Give me a personal guard. Saddle my white horse Surrey for the battle tomorrow. Make sure that my lances are strong, but not too heavy.
og_response: My lord.

translated_dialog: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.
og_response: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!    Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again;    Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain,    But makes one pardon strong.

translated_dialog: How many women saw his child?
og_response: Why, so, brave lords! when we join in league,    I am a lamb: but if you brave the Moor,    The chafed boar, the mountain lioness,    The ocean swells not so as Aaron storms.    But say, again; how many saw the child?

translated_dialog: Richmond? The last time I was in Exeter, the mayor politely showed me a castle and called it "Rougemont." The name startled me, for an Irish poet once told me that I wouldn't live long after seeing Richmond.
og_response: My Lord

translated_dialog: Time to be honest.
og_response: That time serves still.

translated_dialog: I believe you; the look on his face said it all. Give me your hand: if you lead me out of here, you can continue to work for me as my servant. My ships are ready and my people are, too, because they had expected to leave two days ago. Leontes is jealous of a very special woman and, because she's so special, his jealousy is intense; because he's a powerful king, his jealousy will be violent, too, and because he thinks he's been betrayed by his best friend, his revenge will be horrific. I'm paralyzed with fear. Let's hope we have a safe journey out and that the queen doesn't become a victim, too, of his delusions. Come on, Camillo. I'll love you as much as I love my own father if you can get me out of here alive. Let's go.
og_response: It is in mine authority to commandThe keys of all the posterns: please your highnessTo take the urgent hour. Come, sir, away.

translated_dialog: I figured. It never rains but it pours; one struggle gives way to another. It's that way with us. Some nearby country is going to take advantage of our weakness. They've sent all these ships to kick us while we're down, and conquer us in our misery, though it'll hardly be difficult for them to overcome us.
og_response: That's the least fear; for, by the semblanceOf their white flags display'd, they bring us peace,And come to us as favourers, not as foes.

translated_dialog: Not if you get out of here without saying another word.
og_response: [as LUCENTIO]  Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?

translated_dialog: It's like this: Baptista is safely taken care of. He's talking with the pretend father of the pretend son.
og_response: And what of him?

translated_dialog: That light isnt daylight, I know it. Its some meteor sent from the sun to be a torchbearer, in order to light your way to Mantua. So stay for a bit longer. You dont have to leave.
og_response: Let me be taen. Let me be put to death.    I am content, so thou wilt have it so.    Ill say yon grey is not the mornings eye.    Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthias brow.    Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat    The vaulty heaven so high above our heads.    I have more care to stay than will to go.    Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so.    How is t, my soul? Lets talk. It is not day.

translated_dialog: Her eyes almost look like they're moving; this art is too realistic.
og_response: I'll draw the curtain:My lord's almost so far transported thatHe'll think anon it lives.

translated_dialog: No, listen to me.
og_response: Nay, but hear me.

translated_dialog: Quiet, please. Let someone who knows what he's talking about speak up. These men are just flattering you, sir, and flattery only fans the fire of sin. When a king's fault is just a spark, flattery is the blast that gives it heat and makes it glow stronger. On the other hand, wise advice is the best tool a king can make use of, since even kings make mistakes sometimes. When Mr. Yes-man over here wishes you good luck, he's flattering you and, really, threatening your life.[He kneels] Forgive me, sir. Hit me if you want. I can't get much lower than here, on my knees.
og_response: All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlookWhat shipping and what lading's in our haven,And then return to us.  [Exeunt Lords]  Helicanus, thouHast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?

translated_dialog: These events are not natural. They keep getting stranger and stranger.[To BOATSWAIN] Tell me, how did you get here?
og_response: If I did think, sir, I were well awake,    Id strive to tell you.   We were dead of sleep    Andhow, we know notall clapped under hatches,    Where but even now with strange and several noises    Of roaring, shrieking, howling, jingling chains,    And more diversity of sounds, all horrible,    We were awaked, straightway at liberty,    Where we, in all her trim, freshly beheld    Our royal, good, and gallant ship,   our Master    Capering to eye her. On a trice, so please you,    Even in a dream were we divided from them    And were brought moping hither.

translated_dialog: The Duke sends his greetings, General. And he orders you to come appear before him immediately, right this very instant.
og_response: Whats the matter, think you?

translated_dialog: I'm such a fool to cry at the thing that makes me happy.
og_response: [aside]  Fair encounterOf two most rare affections! Heavens rain graceOn that which breeds between 'em!

translated_dialog: Are you a courtier or not, sir?
og_response: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier. Seest    thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings?    hath not my gait in it the measure of the court?    receives not thy nose court-odor from me?   reflect I    not on thy baseness court-contempt?   Thinkest thou,    for that I insinuate, or toaze from thee thy    business, I am therefore no courtier?   I am courtier    cap-a-pe; and one that will either push on or pluck    back thy business there: whereupon I command thee to    open thy affair.

translated_dialog: What?
og_response: No more of drowning, do you hear?

translated_dialog: Thanks for that joke. Here's some clothes in return. Jokes won't go unrewarded when I'm king of this country. Stealing with a plumb-line and carpenter's level is an excellent little joke. Heres some more clothes as a reward.
og_response: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.

translated_dialog: Have you spread the word about her all over the market?
og_response: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs;I have drawn her picture with my voice.

translated_dialog: And please, tell me: how do people seem to be reacting, especially the younger ones?
og_response: 'Faith, they listened to me as they would have    hearkened to their father's testament.   There was a    Spaniard's mouth so watered, that he went to bed to    her very description.

translated_dialog: I thank you for that, master.
og_response: If thou more murmurst, I will rend an oak    And peg thee in his knotty entrails   till    Thou hast howled away twelve winters.

translated_dialog: Tunis used to be Carthage, sir.
og_response: Carthage?

translated_dialog: Is anyone listening to me?
og_response: Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness,    My women may be with me; for you see    My plight requires it.   Do not weep, good fools;    There is no cause: when you shall know your mistress    Has deserved prison, then abound in tears    As I come out: this action I now go on    Is for my better grace.   Adieu, my lord:    I never wish'd to see you sorry; now    I trust I shall.   My women, come; you have leave.

translated_dialog: Is the worst well? Very well taken, in truth, very wise.
og_response: If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.

translated_dialog: Please, sir. Now is not the time to talk about this. Keep your questions until after dinner, then I will tell you why you have not repaid these debts.
og_response: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd.

translated_dialog: Good madam, don't be angry with the child.
og_response: Pitchers have ears.

translated_dialog: Honest, yes, honest.
og_response: My lord, for aught I know.

translated_dialog: If you want your eyes scratched out, then come at me. I'll leave on my own, but first I have to do what I came for. The good queen (because she is good) has given birth to your daughter. Here she is, now give her your blessing.
og_response: Out!A mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door:A most intelligencing bawd!

translated_dialog: [Taking the money] This afternoon, sir? She will be there.
og_response: And stay, good Nurse. Behind the abbey wall    Within this hour my man shall be with thee    And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair,    Which to the high top-gallant of my joy    Must be my convoy in the secret night.    Farewell. Be trusty, and Ill quit thy pains.    Farewell. Commend me to thy mistress.

translated_dialog: I've described her down to every last hair. I've drawn a picture of her with my voice.
og_response: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find theinclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

translated_dialog: God bless you, and fill you with humility, love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
og_response: [standing]  Amen.  [aside]  And make me die a good old man! That is the butt end of a mothers blessing;I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.

translated_dialog: What is she looking for? Lavinia, do you want me to read? This is the tragic story of Philomel, who was raped by Tereusand rape, I fear, was what happened to you.
og_response: See, brother, see; note how she quotes the leaves.

translated_dialog: Because I would have lost the angry wit I now have if I were a lord. Aren't you a merchant?
og_response: Ay, Apemantus.

translated_dialog: That's how you've interpreted it: it's your fault then.
og_response: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

translated_dialog: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
og_response: O, ay, Curtis, ay, and therefore fire, fire. Cast on nowater.

translated_dialog: [To CASSIO] Who are you that's crying out in such pain?
og_response: Iago? Oh, I am spoiled, undone by villains!Give me some help.

translated_dialog: Oh, sir!
og_response: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,    Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts    How I might stop this tempest ere it came;    And finding little comfort to relieve them,    I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

translated_dialog: Yes, it's monstrous, monstrous! That's how it is for Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey. And that's how it will be soon for some other men who think they're as safe as you and I arewe who are dear to princely Richard and Buckingham.
og_response: The princes both make high account of you  [aside]  For they account his head upon the Bridge.

translated_dialog: Oh, happy outcome from my kneeling! But I am still afraid; say it again. Two pardons is better than one.
og_response: With all my heartI pardon him.

translated_dialog: Guys, what do you want me to say? The gods hear me when I say that I am as broke as you are.
og_response: Such a house broke!    So noble a master fall'n! All gone!   and not    One friend to take his fortune by the arm,    And go along with him!

translated_dialog: No, but I am resolved on two points.
og_response: That if one break, the other will hold.   Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.

translated_dialog: The gods, through you, amaze us. You've secured your fame forever.
og_response: She is alive; behold,    Her eyelids, cases to those heavenly jewels    Which Pericles hath lost,    Begin to part their fringes of bright gold;    The diamonds of a most praised water    Do appear, to make the world twice rich.   Live,    And make us weep to hear your fate, fair creature,    Rare as you seem to be.

translated_dialog: I swear I'll hit you if you strike me again.
og_response: So may you lose your arms.If you strike me, you are no gentleman;And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

translated_dialog: [Speaking to the door of the tomb] You hateful mouth, you womb of death. Youve feasted on the most precious girl on earth. So now Im going to force open your rotten jaws and cram more food into you. [ROMEO begins to open the tomb with his tools]
og_response: [Aside]   This is that banished haughty Montague,    That murdered my loves cousin, with which grief,    It is supposed the fair creature died.    And here is come to do some villainous shame    To the dead bodies. I will apprehend him.    [To ROMEO]   Stop thy unhallowed toil, vile Montague!    Can vengeance be pursued further than death?    Condemnèd villain, I do apprehend thee.    Obey and go with me, for thou must die.

translated_dialog: Sweet saint, for goodness's sake, don't be so harsh.
og_response: Foul devil, for Gods sake, hence, and trouble us not,    For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,    Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.    If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,    Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.

translated_dialog: How are things going, Roderigo?
og_response: I do follow here in the chase not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry. My money is almostspent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains.   And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.

translated_dialog: I'm afraid to know, sir.
og_response: How! dare not! do not. Do you know, and dare not?    Be intelligent to me: 'tis thereabouts;    For, to yourself, what you do know, you must.    And cannot say, you dare not.   Good Camillo,    Your changed complexions are to me a mirror    Which shows me mine changed too;   for I must be    A party in this alteration, finding    Myself thus alter'd with 't.

translated_dialog: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beautybut please, tell me if you're really the lady of the house, for I've never actually seen her. I would hate to throw away my speech on the wrong person, for it is excellently written and was very hard for me to memorize. Good beauties, please don't scorn me. I'm very sensitive, even to the slightest bit of rudeness.
og_response: Whence came you, sir?

translated_dialog: Oh villains, vipers, damn them to hell! Dogs, easily won to slobber over any man! Snakes, nurtured in my own blood, that now sting my heart! Three Judases, each one three times worse than Judas! They want peace? Let hell make war on their souls for this!
og_response: Sweet love, I see, changing his property,    Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate:    Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made    With heads, and not with hands;   those whom you curse    Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound    And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.

translated_dialog: Gentlemen, will you go raise men for battle? I don't  know how or which way to order the disorderly affairs that have been thrust into my hands, believe me. Both are of my family: the one is my sovereign, whom both my oath and duty bids me to defend; the other is also my kinsman, who the king has wronged, and conscience and my family bids me to fight for his rights. Well, we have to do something.
og_response: The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland,    But none returns   . For us to levy power    Proportionable to the enemy    Is all unpossible.

translated_dialog: Why should you be afraid? Doesn't the city have strong defenses?
og_response: Ay, but the citizens favor Lucius,And will revolt from me to succor him.

translated_dialog: I cannot believe that those outraged at wicked men should still ask for money!
